summary: A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake and health assessments in July 2019. The most significant entry documents an injury assessment on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck and placed on suicide watch, though he claimed not to know how the injury occurred. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and subsequent medical encounters in July 2019 at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). It includes a detailed history and physical, vital signs, diagnoses, medications, and administrative notes from the period just prior to his death. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and administrative notes, culminating in the assessment following an incident on July 23 where Epstein was found with a string around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch. The records detail his psychological state, denials of suicidality, and interactions with staff. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein, including a Diagnostic and Care Level Formulation and multiple Suicide Risk Assessments conducted on July 9, 2019, following his return from court the previous day. The assessments were conducted as a precaution due to risk factors but concluded Epstein was at low acute suicide risk with no mental health diagnosis. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment, suicide risk evaluation, and medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-14, 2019, shortly after his arrest. It includes mental health evaluations, risk assessments for suicide and sexual abusiveness, and medical test results, all indicating Epstein was assessed as low risk for suicide and sexual abusiveness while in custody.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the Bureau of Prisons psychological and medical intake assessments. He is evaluated for suicide risk, mental health status, and risk of sexual abusiveness while incarcerated at MCC New York.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: Medical provider who conducted the comprehensive history and physical examination of Epstein on July 9, 2019, and prescribed initial medication.

persons.name: PA-C
persons.context: The healthcare provider who conducted Epstein's initial health screening on July 6, 2019, documenting his medical history and vital signs.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The chief psychologist who conducted multiple clinical interventions, SHU reviews, and administrative notes regarding Epstein's mental status and complaints from July 9-18, 2019.

persons.name: Dental Asst
persons.context: Dental staff member who documented a failed dental screening encounter on July 18, 2019, due to Epstein not being escorted to the clinic.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: A psychologist (Doctor of Psychology) who conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 23, 2019, after he was found with a string around his neck.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Notified the on-call psychologist around 2 AM on July 23, 2019, that Epstein was being placed on suicide watch after being found with a string around his neck.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Was notified by the assessing psychologist about Epstein's statement to staff that his cellmate tried to kill him; the Captain stated they were already aware.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he does not have a close relationship, identified as a static risk factor for suicide due to lack of family connections.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as someone he wanted to meet with and whom he described as 'competent,' expressing confidence in his legal representation.

persons.name: Robert Nagle
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office consulted by the chief psychologist regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors and monitoring procedures.

connections.description: MLP was the medical provider who assessed Epstein after he was found injured in his cell on July 23, 2019.
MD was the physician who managed Epstein's chronic medical conditions and prescribed medications during his incarceration.
PA-C conducted Epstein's initial medical intake screening upon his arrival at the facility.
MD cosigned the medical note written by MLP regarding Epstein's injury on July 23, 2019.
PsyD conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 23, 2019, following the incident with the string.
The chief psychologist had multiple clinical contacts with Epstein, addressing his complaints and assessing his mental status from July 9-18, 2019.
The Operations Lieutenant was involved in the decision to place Epstein on suicide watch and notified psychology staff of the incident on July 23, 2019.
Both are psychology staff members within the Bureau of Prisons documenting assessments and interventions for the same inmate.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated they do not have a close relationship.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as competent, and requested to meet with him.
The psychologist conducted multiple clinical interviews and suicide risk assessments of Epstein as part of Bureau of Prisons protocol.
Dr. Nagle was consulted by the assessing psychologist regarding Epstein's risk factors and monitoring needs.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell in the Special Housing Unit with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He was assessed by medical staff, placed on suicide watch, and claimed not to know how the injury occurred.

events.title: Initial Medical Intake Screening
events.description: Epstein underwent a comprehensive health screening upon intake, documenting his medical history, vital signs, and risk factors.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by a physician for chronic conditions including hyperlipidemia, back pain, and sleep apnea. Medications were prescribed.

events.title: Follow-up Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: A follow-up physician evaluation for Epstein's chronic medical conditions, with additional lab tests ordered.

events.title: Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's first medical encounter at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM), including vital signs and PPD placement.

events.title: Comprehensive History & Physical
events.description: A detailed medical examination of Epstein documenting his personal history, sexual history (10+ female partners in last 5 years), past chlamydia infection, and current physical and mental health status.

events.title: Medical Diagnoses and Treatment
events.description: Epstein diagnosed with several conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, low back pain, and neuralgia. Prescribed Medrol Dose Pack for back pain and other medications.

events.title: Documentation of Injury
events.description: Medical record notes an 'Injury, unspecified' with the comment 'RIO self inflicted injuries.'

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found by SHU staff in his cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. He was placed on suicide watch. The incident prompted a suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A precautionary suicide risk assessment was conducted on Epstein after he returned from court. He denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidality, or substance abuse.

events.title: Epstein Placed in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: SHU Review Attempt
events.description: A scheduled SHU review for Epstein could not be completed because he was meeting with his legal team and had a court hearing.

events.title: Epstein returns from court proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from court after duty hours, prompting staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation due to risk factors including potential bad news from his legal proceeding.

events.title: Psychological suicide risk assessments
events.description: Multiple psychological assessments conducted on Epstein, including a Diagnostic and Care Level Formulation and Suicide Risk Assessments, concluding he was at low acute suicide risk with no mental health diagnosis.

events.title: Epstein placed on psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation status upon return from court due to risk factors including high-profile case, sex offense charges, and recent court proceeding.

events.title: Previous incarceration in Palm Beach County
events.description: Epstein reported serving time in Palm Beach County jail on sex offense charges (soliciting prostitution) in the past.

events.title: Psychological Intake Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial psychological intake screening at MCC New York. He denies mental health history, suicidal ideation, and expresses optimism about his legal case.

events.title: Risk of Sexual Abusiveness Assessment
events.description: Psychology staff assess Epstein's risk for sexual abusiveness in the prison setting, identifying him as low risk based on history but noting prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A comprehensive suicide risk assessment is conducted following a court proceeding. Epstein is found to have a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk, despite identified risk factors.

events.title: Medical Laboratory Tests
events.description: Blood and other medical tests are collected from Epstein, showing results including high cholesterol and triglycerides, and a hemoglobin A1C indicating increased risk for diabetes.

events.title: Refusal of Medical Treatment
events.description: Epstein refuses a recommended chest X-ray, signing a form acknowledging the potential consequences of refusing treatment.

locations: Mount Sinai Hospital (mentioned as site of past hospitalization for appendicitis in 1990)
Paris (mentioned as travel destination prior to arrest)
1900 W. Sunshine Street, Springfield, MO 65807 (U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisons - lab location)
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck and was placed on suicide watch.
During the medical assessment for the neck injury, Epstein stated, 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting' and could not explain the marks on his neck.
The medical record notes a 'circular line of erythema at the base of the neck' consistent with the reported incident and classifies the injury as 'self inflicted injuries.'
Epstein's medical history included hypertriglyceridemia, obstructive sleep apnea (for which he used a CPAP machine), and severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis causing numbness and shooting pain.

An intake screening on July 6, 2019, recorded Epstein's travel history (including recent travel to Paris), sexual history (10+ female partners in last 5 years), and a past diagnosis of chlamydia in 2015.
Epstein's medical intake documented he had '10+' female sexual partners in the last 5 years, sometimes used condoms, and had a history of chlamydia in 2015.
On July 23, 2019, a medical entry for 'Injury, unspecified' included the comment 'RIO self inflicted injuries,' which is a highly significant notation given subsequent events.
Epstein was diagnosed with several medical conditions in custody including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, constipation, and low back pain, for which he received prescriptions.
The records show he refused parts of the physical exam (rectal and male genitalia exams) on July 9, 2019.
A dental screening scheduled for July 18, 2019, was not completed because Epstein 'has not been escorted to the dental clinic' despite several call outs.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.
Epstein told staff watching him that his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist.
Psychological assessments from July 9-23 consistently noted Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse.
The suicide risk assessment on July 23 concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Moderate' and his chronic risk was 'Absent'; he was to remain on suicide watch for observation.

Epstein made numerous complaints about his conditions in SHU, including lack of property, cold cells, uniform issues, and desire for a single cell, which were documented and addressed by psychology and custody staff.

On July 9, 2019, Bureau of Prisons psychologists assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having low acute suicide risk and no mental health diagnosis, despite multiple risk factors including high-profile case and sex trafficking charges.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse, and reported his only family was a brother with whom he was not close.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court on July 8, 2019, due to concerns about potential bad news regarding his legal situation.
The assessment noted Epstein was future-oriented, expressed a commitment to life, had confidence in his attorney, and believed he would be released at an upcoming bail hearing.
Epstein reported previous incarceration in Palm Beach County jail on soliciting prostitution charges before facing federal sex trafficking charges.

On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' overall acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, despite noting risk factors like his high-profile case and lack of family connection.
Epstein was assessed as 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the prison, though the assessment noted his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
Epstein expressed a positive outlook on his legal case during assessments, mentioning an upcoming bail hearing and belief he would be released, and described his attorney as 'competent.'
Epstein refused a recommended chest X-ray on July 10, 2019, signing a Bureau of Prisons treatment refusal form.
Medical tests from July 9, 2019, showed Epstein had high cholesterol (216 mg/dL), high triglycerides (413 mg/dL), and a hemoglobin A1C of 6.3%, indicating increased risk for diabetes.
